posts.name: WarrenR
posts.cooked: Hi Everyone, Does anyone know a free way of flattening a curved STEP file for cutting out on a CNC? We are trying to make the Cone of the Upper Hub for 2022 FRC Game. Part No TE-22197. Link to STEP File Thanks

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
I assume the “complex” team field drawings/CAD are pretty close https://firstfrc.blob.core.windows.net/frc2022/FieldAssets/Assembly1_Complex.zip

That has files and drawings for 4 1/8 lexan quarter-cone pieces

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: WarrenR
posts.cooked:
That drawing is on a page of a multipage pdf document and doesn’t contain many dimensions.  That’s why I was trying to use CAD Model instead. But I suppose I could bring in as picture and then trace over as a last resort.  I was just hoping someone would say, do ABC and its done.

Or are you saying that one of those many solidworks file is actually a CAD file of the layout?.  I don’t know how to drive solidworks.  But I can import a single file into Fusion 360 if someone can identify the solidwork file I need to import.

posts.name: Zach Stachelczyk
posts.cooked:
Evening,

Does it have to be the step file? The Solidworks part TE-22197 has a flat configuration available for use. I would be happy to send you a DXF of the flat component if that would be helpful. Shoot me a message with your email address if you would like a copy.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: You can take the same diameters in Onshape or SW, create a lofted sheet metal part, and then flatten thay.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: @warren.reynolds1 The orientation is kind of goofy but these files should give you what you need. TE-22197-flat.zip (61.1 KB)

link_counts.title: CAD for routing out field elements

posts.name: WarrenR
posts.cooked: Thanks Sanddrag, That file is exactly what I needed.
